context_of_use: The use case enables designated IFA administrative personnel to create new leagues and register new teams in the system and to have these entities approved by an IFA manager in order to keep the IFA system up to date while maintaining data integrity.
stakeholders_and_interests: ifa administrator: Needs to add new leagues and register new teams in the system to ensure that the league and team data remains current.
ifa manager: Needs to approve newly added leagues and registered teams in order to maintain the integrity and trustworthiness of the data in the system.
IFA organization: Requires that all active leagues and teams are accurately represented and controlled in a single system while ensuring governance and integrity.
Registered teams: Depend on timely and correct registration and approval to participate in competitions under the IFA’s governance.
Leagues: Depend on accurate representation and approval to be officially managed within the IFA system.
description: This use case defines how an IFA administrator creates new leagues and registers new teams in the IFA League Management System and how an IFA manager reviews and approves these leagues and teams to ensure that the system remains up to date and consistent with IFA integrity requirements.
triggering_event: An ifa administrator or ifa manager initiates a session to create or review leagues and teams that must be added to or approved in the system.
preconditions: The IFA League Management System is operational and accessible.
The ifa administrator is authenticated and authorized to add new leagues and register new teams.
The ifa manager is authenticated and authorized to approve leagues and teams.
Required league and team information is available to the ifa administrator prior to data entry.
postconditions: All newly created leagues that have been submitted and approved are stored in the system with an approved status.
All newly registered teams that have been submitted and approved are stored in the system with an approved status.
Leagues and teams that have been created or registered but not yet approved are stored in the system with a clearly identifiable pending-approval status.
The system’s league and team records reflect the latest approved configuration according to IFA integrity requirements.
assumptions: It is assumed that only individuals in the role of ifa administrator can initiate the creation of new leagues and the registration of new teams.
It is assumed that only individuals in the role of ifa manager can perform approvals of leagues and teams created or registered by ifa administrators.

It is assumed that the system maintains internal status values to distinguish between pending and approved leagues and teams, even though these statuses are not explicitly described in the requirement text.
It is assumed that the system validates that mandatory league and team data fields are provided before allowing the ifa administrator to submit them for approval.

It is assumed that the system prevents an ifa manager from modifying the core identity attributes of leagues and teams (such as names and identifiers) during the approval step and limits them to approve or reject decisions.

It is assumed that when the requirement mentions keeping the system up to date, it refers solely to data correctness and completeness regarding leagues and teams and does not imply any additional synchronization with external systems.

It is assumed that the system maintains an audit trail of league and team creation, registration, and approval actions for integrity, even though audit functionality is not explicitly mentioned, and that this audit storage does not introduce new externally visible capabilities.
It is assumed that there is no automatic or implicit approval; every league and team must be explicitly approved by an ifa manager before being considered active for operational use.
It is assumed that the same use case is used both when creating the first league or team in the system and when adding additional leagues or teams at a later time.
requirements_met: The system shall allow an authenticated ifa administrator to add new leagues to the system so that the league data remains up to date.
The system shall allow an authenticated ifa administrator to register new teams in the system so that the team data remains up to date.
The system shall require that newly added leagues are approved by an authenticated ifa manager before they are treated as fully valid in the system so that data integrity is maintained.
The system shall require that newly registered teams are approved by an authenticated ifa manager before they are treated as fully valid in the system so that data integrity is maintained.
The system shall store the relationship between leagues and their registered teams so that participation can be managed under the IFA system.
The system shall record the outcome of each approval decision for a league or team, including whether it was approved or left pending, so that the integrity of administrative actions is maintained.
outstanding_issues: The business rules for what specific criteria an ifa manager should apply when approving or rejecting a league are not defined.
The business rules for what specific criteria an ifa manager should apply when approving or rejecting a team are not defined.
Policies for naming conventions, uniqueness constraints, and identifiers for leagues and teams are not described.
It is unclear whether multiple ifa managers can approve the same league or team or if only a single approval is allowed.
It is not defined whether a previously approved league or team can later be revoked or deactivated and, if so, how this should be handled.
The maximum allowed number of leagues and teams in the system, if any, is not specified.
The required data fields and validation rules for leagues and teams (for example, contact information, geographic region, or competition level) are not specified.
main_flow: 1. ifa administrator initiates league and team management → System displays league and team administration options including functions to add new leagues and register new teams.
2. ifa administrator selects the option to add a new league → System presents a form for entering new league details required for creation.

3. ifa administrator enters the new league details and submits the league for registration → System validates the league data and, if valid, creates a new league record with a status indicating that approval by an ifa manager is required.
4. ifa administrator selects the option to register a new team → System presents a form for entering new team details required for registration.

5. ifa administrator enters the new team details, associates the team with a league if required, and submits the team for registration → System validates the team data and, if valid, creates a new team record with a status indicating that approval by an ifa manager is required.
6. ifa manager opens the league and team approval interface → System displays a list of leagues and teams that are pending approval with their key details.
7. ifa manager selects a pending league for review → System displays the full details of the selected league for decision.
8. ifa manager records an approval decision for the league → System updates the league record to reflect that it has been approved and makes the league available as an approved league in the system.
9. ifa manager selects a pending team for review → System displays the full details of the selected team, including any associated league, for decision.
10. ifa manager records an approval decision for the team → System updates the team record to reflect that it has been approved and makes the team available as an approved team in the system.

11. ifa manager and ifa administrator end their league and team management activities → System confirms that all processed leagues and teams retain their final stored statuses and remains available for further administrative use.
alternative_flows: AF-1 (from Step 2): ifa administrator decides not to add a new league after viewing the league creation form → System closes the league creation form without creating a new league record and returns to the league and team administration options; the use case then continues with any other administrative action such as Step 4 or ends.

AF-2 (from Step 4): ifa administrator decides not to register a new team after viewing the team registration form → System closes the team registration form without creating a new team record and returns to the league and team administration options; the use case may continue with Step 2 or end.

AF-3 (from Step 6): ifa manager chooses to approve only leagues or only teams during the session → System allows the ifa manager to review and approve a subset of pending leagues or teams and leaves any unprocessed items in a pending status; the use case ends when the ifa manager closes the approval interface.

AF-4 (from Step 8): ifa manager reviews the league details and decides to defer the decision → System keeps the league in pending status and returns to the list of pending leagues and teams; the use case may continue with Step 9 or end.

AF-5 (from Step 10): ifa manager reviews the team details and decides to defer the decision → System keeps the team in pending status and returns to the list of pending leagues and teams; the use case may continue with further approvals from Step 6 or end.
exception_flows: EF-1 (from Step 3): The system detects that the provided league data is invalid or violates a uniqueness rule during submission → System rejects the league creation request, displays validation error messages describing the issues, and allows the ifa administrator to correct the league data and resubmit; the main flow resumes at Step 3 after correction.

EF-2 (from Step 5): The system detects that the provided team data is invalid or violates a uniqueness rule during submission → System rejects the team registration request, displays validation error messages describing the issues, and allows the ifa administrator to correct the team data and resubmit; the main flow resumes at Step 5 after correction.

EF-3 (from Step 6): The system cannot retrieve the list of pending leagues and teams due to an internal error or data unavailability → System displays an error message indicating that pending items cannot be loaded and prevents further approvals during this session; the use case terminates without changing any league or team statuses.

EF-4 (from Step 8): The system fails to update the league record to approved status due to a storage or connectivity error → System displays an error message to the ifa manager, logs the failure, and leaves the league in pending status; the ifa manager may attempt the approval again at a later time, and the current instance of the use case ends for that league.

EF-5 (from Step 10): The system fails to update the team record to approved status due to a storage or connectivity error → System displays an error message to the ifa manager, logs the failure, and leaves the team in pending status; the ifa manager may attempt the approval again at a later time, and the current instance of the use case ends for that team.
information_for_steps: 1. Actor identity, session context, available administrative permissions.
2. League creation option selection, navigation context.
3. League name, league identifier, competition level, associated region or country, any other mandatory league attributes, league status set to pending approval.
4. Team registration option selection, selection of associated league if required.
5. Team name, team identifier, associated league reference, contact details if required, any other mandatory team attributes, team status set to pending approval.
6. List of pending leagues and teams, including identifiers, names, and current pending statuses.
7. Detailed league information including identifiers, descriptive attributes, and current status.
8. Approval decision flag for the league, timestamp of decision, identity of the ifa manager making the decision, updated league status set to approved.
9. Detailed team information including identifiers, associated league reference, descriptive attributes, and current status.
10. Approval decision flag for the team, timestamp of decision, identity of the ifa manager making the decision, updated team status set to approved.
11. Summary of any leagues and teams processed during the session, final stored statuses for leagues and teams, session termination context.
